review.title: A collaborative ant colony metaheuristic for distributed multi-level lot-sizing
review.abstract: The paper presents an ant colony optimization metaheuristic for collaborative planning. Collaborative planning is used to coordinate individual plans of self-interested decision makers with private information in order to increase the overall benefit of the coalition. The method consists of a new search graph based on encoded solutions. Distributed and private information is integrated via voting mechanisms and via a simple but effective collaborative local search procedure. The approach is applied to a distributed variant of the multi-level lot-sizing problem and evaluated by means of 352 benchmark instances from the literature. The proposed approach clearly outperforms existing approaches on the sets of medium and large sized instances. While the best method in the literature so far achieves an average deviation from the best known non-distributed solutions of 46 percent for the set of the largest instances, for example, the presented approach reduces the average deviation to only 5 percent.

sections.heading: 2.1 Classical centralized problem formulation
sections.text: The distributed batch size model examined in this paper covers the well-known multi-stage, uncapacitated batch size problem (MLULSP, cf. Yelle 1979, Steinberg and Napier 1980, Dellaert and Jeunet 2000). Therefore, the MLULSP is first presented using the notation given in Table 1. MLULSP assumes a single decision maker who is aware of all the information required for planning, in particular the setup costs and inventory maintenance costs per item and period. A formal description of the MLULSP is given by formulas (1) to (8).min fnd (y) = a single decision item, which indicates all the setup and inventory maintenance costs per item and period.

sections.heading: 2.2 Extension to a distributed group decision problem formulation
sections.text: Following Homberger (2010), the MLULSP is now expanded to include a distributed group decision problem known as the Distributed Multi-Level Uncapacitated Lot-Sizing (DMLUSLSP) problem. Instead of a single decision maker or agent responsible for the production of all items I, the responsibility is jointly assigned to a group of Agent A. Each agent is responsible for the production of the totality of items Ia = I and a = Ia. For example, an agent could be a profit center or an independent company, and the agents could interact in a supply chain. All agents are autonomous and self-serving.

3.1 Overview
sections.text: A metaheuristic solution approach based on ant colony optimization (ACO) is presented, which takes into account in particular the distributed nature of DMLULSP. The distributed solution approach is called a collaborative ant colony metaheuristic (CACM). An overview is given by Alg. 1. The metaheuristic CACM works on an encrypted representation of a DMLULSP solution, which is described in Sect. 3.2. Components of an encrypted solution are represented by a searchgraph G, which is traversed by artificial ants to construct encrypted solutions. Sect. 3.3 presents the searchgraph G and Sect. 3.4 presents the stochastic ant building method. Each constructed solution is improved by a collaborative local search (cf. Sect. 3.5). Both, the graph structure used and the local search heuristic integrate new concepts in comparison to the metaheuristic solutions (2011) and (cf. Sect. 3.5).

sections.heading: 3.2.1 Solution encoding
sections.text: The binary decision variables yit represent the setup decisions indicating whether item i is produced at all in period t. Due to the structure of the MLULSP, it is possible to determine the optimal lot sizes xit when the optimal setup decisions yit are known (Dellaert and Jeunet, 2000). Therefore, the proposed CACM focuses its search efforts on approximating the optimal setup decisions. sections.text: A coded solution e- {0, 1} m · n is converted into a DMLULSP solution in a two-step procedure. The product level of an article i determines the order in which demand, lot size xit and stock lighting are calculated. The procedure begins with the lowest positions (end products) and advances in positions with increasing product level. That is, the requirements for the end products (level 0) are first determined, the requirements for level 1 items are calculated next and so on (cf. Homberger (2008). Therefore, the items are considered in the order of their non-decreasing product level. If article i is an end product (level 1), then the demand is calculated for all articles 1 ≤ j ≤ T. sections.heading: 3.3.2 Initialization of pheromone trail
sections.text: The order of the directed edges crossed by an ant depends on the pheromone value τ (i, j) set at each edge (i, j). Higher pheromone values τ (i, j) at an edge (i, j) increase the probability of an ant crossing the edge (i, j). Homberger and Gehring (2009) proposed an ACO approach for a (not distributed) MLULSP on a different search curve and successfully pursued the idea of constructing every possible solution with equal probability ("balanced path") first. In contrast to this idea, the aim of this approach is to construct unbalanced paths consisting mainly of black knots first. According to the Max Min Ant System proposed by (Pillar and Hoos, 2000), for each edge (i, j) a minimum and maximum pheromone value (i, j) and an initial value (j) are set to 1.

sections.heading: 3.6.1 Complete approval voting
sections.text: In the admission vote, each agent can vote for as many candidate solutions in B as he wants, and the solution with the most approvals wins (Brams and Fishburn, 1978). For the present problem, a modified and limited version of the admission vote is used, which is referred to by the term full admission vote. An encrypted candidate solution e is only accepted as the winner if all agents approve a. Therefore, by adopting e, no agent increases its current local costs C х a, i.e., Ca (e) ≤ C х a, Ñ a. For complete admission votes, the voting size is b = 1. Although this voting rule is quite simple, it was not applied in the previous approaches Hombergers (2010, 2011) and Hombergers and Gehrings (2011).

In view of all evaluations by all agents, in the Borda rule the candidate solution e is selected that maximizes the lowest score assigned by an agent to a candidate solution. Finally, the solution e ², which was identified by Borda voting, is compared with the jointly accepted solution e ² by full consent. The winning solution becomes the new jointly accepted solution e ².

sections.text: The Minimax voting rule introduced by Rawls (1971) minimizes an intermediary's maximum local costs. sections.heading: 4 Evaluation

sections.heading: 4.1 Setup of computational study

sections.heading: 4.1.1 Goals
sections.text: The evaluation of the metaheuristic CACM is carried out by means of a computational benchmark study. Three objectives are pursued: firstly, the effects of the three voting rules in Section 3.6 are examined; secondly, the effect of the new collaborative local search heurism CLS from Section 3.5 is tested; thirdly, the performance of the CACM is compared with results from the literature, i.e. with the best known solutions for the undistributed MLULSP and other heuristics for the distributed MLULSP.

sections.heading: 4.1.2 Instances
sections.text: In total, 528 benchmark instances are used in this study1. Veral and LaForge (1985), Coleman and McKnew (1991) and Dellaert and Jeunet (2000) introduced 176 instances for the non-distributed MLULSP. In these cases, a single agent (| A | = 1) is responsible for the production of all items and the instances are divided into three groups of small, medium and large instances, called s1, m1 and l1 (see Table 2). Based on these MLULSP instances, Homberger (2010) introduced 176 instances in which the items are produced jointly by two agents (| A | = 2) and 176 instances in which the items are produced jointly by five agents (| A | = 5). Accordingly, these 352 DMLULSP instances are divided into six groups, which are called s2, s5, m5, l2 and l5 (see Table 2 and l5).

sections.heading: 4.1.4 Implementation and hardware
sections.text: CACM was implemented in JAVA (JDK 1.6). Computational experiments were performed on a Linux PC with Intel Core 2 Duo processor 1.83 GHz. To compare the heuristics in paragraph 4.4, all experiments were performed on this computer.

sections.heading: 4.1.5 Parameters
sections.text: By means of a preliminary study, the parameters of the CACM shown in Table 3 were determined. In all cases, the pheromone evaporation rate ρ, the pheromone intensification factor σ and the minimum pheromone value τmin per edge are constant. On the other hand, the number of produced solutions s and the maximum pheromone value τmax per edge increase with increasing instance size. Ballot size b is evaluated together with the voting rules in the next section.

sections.heading: 4.2 Effect of voting rules and ballot size
sections.text: The effects of the on-board and Rawls voting rules on the performance of the CACM are examined using the benchmark instances of groups s2 and s5. Both voting rules are applied using ballot sizes b of 1, 10, 20 and 100. Results are shown in Table 4.The configuration of the on-board and Rawls ballots with a ballot size of b = 1 results in equivalent voting procedures and thus in identical results (see Table 4). Especially in scenarios with five agents, the results of the Borda voting rule are slightly better than the results of the Rawls voting rule. However, in the scenario with five agents, both voting rules lead to the best results for ballot sizes of only one. In the two agent scenarios, ballot sizes lead to the second-best results. Overall, both voting rules appear to result in higher total costs than in the degenerated case (b = 1). Therefore, the vote size A parameter is set on the "Voting Strategic" (i.e. the Voting B function is activated in the local case).

sections.heading: 4.3 Effect of collaborative local search
sections.text: The CACM approach including collaborative local search (CLS, cf. Section 3,5) is compared to CACM without CLS, the latter being referred to as CACMex. As described above, only full approval coordination is used. Furthermore, CLS is used as a stand-alone heuristics following Alg. 1 without the constructEncodedSolution procedure. The original encoded solution e is placed on the Unit Matrix. The three variants are compared against the instances from groups s1, s2 and s5. CACM removes 80 out of 96 instances to optimality. For the remaining 16 instances, the average optimality gap is only 0.07 percent, although CACM does not show the specific CLULSP solution and the Cheux-distributed Ceux combination forms the overall scenario faster than the Ceux-1.

sections.heading: 4.4 Comparison with heuristics from the literature
sections.text: CACM is compared with three approaches designed for the DMLUSLP, referred to here as SA, ES and ACO, which are based on the metaheuristics of simulated annealing, evolutionary strategy and ant colony optimization, respectively. SA was introduced by (Homberger, 2010), ES is presented in Homberger (2011) and ACO is discussed in (Homberger and Gehring, 2010, 2011) Some of these earlier calculation experiments have been repeated or expanded to include additional cases (see Section 4.1.4).Table 6 shows the average gap G over 176 cases with two agents (classes s2, m2, l2) and over 176 cases with five agents (classes s5, m5, l5).The detailed results for medium and large cases are compared in Tables 7, 8, 9, 9 and 10 cases with two agents (classes s2, l2).CACM due to the long maturities Homberger and Gehring (2010, 2011) compared their approach with only the means of large groups and large instances.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusions
sections.text: A collaborative approach based on metaheuristic ant colony optimization was presented to coordinate the joint production planning of a coalition of self-interested decision-makers with asymmetrical information. The search process is conducted by a mediator who is unaware of the agents "local costs. Furthermore, agents do not have to disclose private cost information when searching. However, in order to control the search process, the mediator tries to find preferences through coordination and a new collaborative local search method. Results are used to update the pheromone information that guides the solution process. Solutions are constructed on the basis of a new graph structure based on encrypted solutions that are less complicated and therefore easier to search. The new approach CACM is evaluated on 356 benchmark instances from the literature and surpasses all existing distributed planning approaches on the basis of middle- and large-scale instances. For future research, it appears interesting to examine non-collaborative issues with a large-collaborative approach.

As to computational experiments, a variety of benchmark instances is available in the literature which allow for comparative test including other approaches. Lot Sizing Problems are of high relevance in modern supply chains (Voßand Woodruff, 2006). Surveys of the rich literature on lot sizing problems are given for example by Drexl and Kimms (1997), Jans and Degraeve (2007), or Winands et al. (2011). Integration of lot sizing with cooperative game theory is discussed by Drechsel and Kimms (2010, 2011). Metaheuristic solution approaches for the non-distributed MLULSP are amongst others presented by Dellaert and Jeunet (2000, 2003), Pitakaso et al. (2007), Homberger (2008), Xiao et al. (2011), and Xiao et al. (2012). The literature discusses at least two distributed lot sizing variants. The one studied by Lee and Kumara (2007b,a) is based on auctions and has been tested on small size instances. For the other, the distributed MLULSP, several metaheuristic approaches that integrate concepts from group decision making are known in the literature: a simulated annealing approach (SA, Homberger, 2010), an approach based on an evolutionary strategy (ES, Homberger, 2011) and one based on ant colony optimization (ACO, Homberger and Gehring, 2010, 2011). These approaches differ by the used metaheuristic principle, the applied negotiation or voting mechanisms, and the relevant objective functions (minimizing total global cost or maximizing fairness). ES is especially useful for maximizing fairness. SA and ACO strive to minimize total global cost. In terms of solution quality, ACO outperforms SA on medium sized instances (40 and 50 items with 12 and 24 periods) but not on small or large instances (500 items, and 36 or 52 periods). Furthermore, ACO is significantly slower than SA on small, medium, and large instances. The aim of this paper is to present a new collaborative ant colony metaheuristic (CACM) for solving the DMLULSP under global total cost minimization. metadata.abstractText: The paper presents an ant colony optimization metaheuristic for collaborative planning. Collaborative planning is used to coordinate individual plans of self-interested decision makers with private information in order to increase the overall benefit of the coalition. The method consists of a new search graph based on encoded solutions. Distributed and private information is integrated via voting mechanisms and via a simple but effective collaborative local search procedure. The approach is applied to a distributed variant of the multi-level lot-sizing problem and evaluated by means of 352 benchmark instances from the literature. The proposed approach clearly outperforms existing approaches on the sets of medium and large sized instances. While the best method in the literature so far achieves an average deviation from the best known non-distributed solutions of 46 percent for the set of the largest instances, for example, the presented approach reduces the average deviation to only 5 percent.
